parts:
Hi o1. Today we are going to be collecting evidence for a research paper. 

# Ground rules

ABOVE ALL ELSE, if you are unsure about something, or do not have evidence from a web page supporting a claim, do not make a claim. If there is any doubt, there is no doubt.

This is research. SPEND EXTRA TIME above and beyond normal, to collect data carefully and methodically. We don't care about how long it takes, only that your research is accurate and epistemologically grounded. Care and attention to detail second only to the prior rule.

# Definitions

## Tool definition
For our project, a software tool is any discrete piece of software—be it a program, script, or web application—that is developed or substantially modified by researchers to perform specific, research-oriented computational tasks. These tasks must involve active data processing, such as analysis, simulation, visualization, modeling, or automation, where input data is dynamically created, documented, transformed, or interpreted to generate meaningful results. In contrast, products whose primary function is to simply display, store, or promote static datasets—without offering mechanisms for active computational engagement—are excluded. 

In essence, a valid software tool for our purposes is one that not only **supports research in archaeology or historical sciences** but does so by actively collecting and/or processing data rather than merely serving as a generic data repository or static interface.

It is our belief that the tools we have given you meet this criteria, however, if there is an absence of evidence supporting our belief, it is REQUIRED that you inform us of any problems. IF YOU ARE UNSURE, INDICATE IT rather than giving an answer.

# Task

I will be giving you the name or acronym of an archaeology and historical studies-related software tool which dates somewhere from 1995 onwards. 

You must build a well-formed quoted CSV inside a fenced code block with the following columns:
csv
"Tool", "Year", "Source", "URL", "AI Notes"

* Tool is our key column. It is essential to be consistent in tool name, following the input we give you. If there is an issue indicate it in notes.
* Year, year from the web page, article, or source you found, n.d. is a valid entry for "no date"
* Source: Citation or (Domain + Page Title)
* URL, url of the resource. 
* AI notes: any notes, concerns, or uncertainties you have with the data provenance or quality. Do not use HTML citations.

This is a comprehensive and systematic search. For each year, 1995 onwards, we one mention (one line) per source found. Obviously, many of these tools were created after 1995, so we'll want to expand our search by +- 1 year from any date we find. When you find a source, systematically explore adjacent years in your searches.

DO NOT extrapolate dates from sources. ONLY include dates where a source has been published in that year. We will perform all necessary inference, if you include a line for EACH valid source you find. For undated items, indicate "n.d."

This research requires that you be thoughtful, systematic, and take your time. You will likely need to visit EVERY SINGLE PAGE of search results for a given tool. 

To repeat back.

I'm going to give you a list of tools, one by one.
You will search for them.
For every source you find,  we want to record year/n.d., source (citation or title), and url

You MUST build a CSV with the output in your direct response to the deep research process.

Allowed sources: 
* Do try to find it's source code in published version control repos (add a row if they have public code, as the commits will have dates)
* do try to find scholarly literature (each to one row)
* do include blog posts and about pages (each to one row)
* do include any other mentions of the tool (each to one row)

When you respond with data:
RESULTS: Build a markdown **fenced code block** CSV of evidence you have found with  ANY mention of that tool in ANY year/n.d. should be on the CSV, regardless of source. Include one line for EACH source you find. Do not include any inline citations automatically generated by the deep research process (i.e., AI-generated or system-injected references i.e. 【deep research】 or ​:contentReference[oaicite). 

Do you understand?
Yes, I understand. Please provide the first tool name or acronym, and I will begin the research systematically following the outlined methodology.

Understood. I will conduct a comprehensive and systematic search for all sources mentioning the tool "Spatial Analyst" from 1995 onwards. Each source will be recorded in a well-formed quoted CSV, capturing the tool name, year, source, URL, and any relevant AI notes regarding data provenance or quality. 

I will carefully explore adjacent years for every mention I find, ensuring accuracy and epistemological rigor. I will let you know when the research is ready for review.

content.text:
{"task_violates_safety_guidelines":false,"user_def_doesnt_want_research":false,"response":"Understood. I will conduct a comprehensive and systematic search for all sources mentioning the tool "Spatial Analyst" from 1995 onwards. Each source will be recorded in a well-formed quoted CSV, capturing the tool name, year, source, URL, and any relevant AI notes regarding data provenance or quality. 

I will carefully explore adjacent years for every mention I find, ensuring accuracy and epistemological rigor. I will let you know when the research is ready for review.","title":"Comprehensive Research on Spatial Analyst Tool","prompt":"Conduct a systematic and exhaustive search for any mention of the tool "Spatial Analyst" in archaeological and historical studies research from 1995 onwards. Ensure that each mention is recorded in a well-formed quoted CSV with the following columns: "Tool", "Year", "Source", "URL", and "AI Notes." 

- Include all valid sources such as scholarly literature, blogs, about pages, official repositories, and any public mentions.
- Ensure one line per source found, and explore adjacent years (+/- 1 year) where necessary.
- Do NOT extrapolate dates; only include explicitly stated publication years.
- Clearly indicate if any uncertainties or issues arise regarding data provenance.
- Prioritize accuracy and systematic completeness in data collection.
- Return the results in a markdown fenced code block CSV format without any inline citations generated by the AI system.

This research requires meticulous attention to detail and an exhaustive approach. Ensure full epistemological rigor in every step."}

metadata.async_task_title: Comprehensive Research on Spatial Analyst Tool
metadata.async_task_prompt:
Conduct a systematic and exhaustive search for any mention of the tool "Spatial Analyst" in archaeological and historical studies research from 1995 onwards. Ensure that each mention is recorded in a well-formed quoted CSV with the following columns: "Tool", "Year", "Source", "URL", and "AI Notes." 

- Include all valid sources such as scholarly literature, blogs, about pages, official repositories, and any public mentions.
- Ensure one line per source found, and explore adjacent years (+/- 1 year) where necessary.
- Do NOT extrapolate dates; only include explicitly stated publication years.
- Clearly indicate if any uncertainties or issues arise regarding data provenance.
- Prioritize accuracy and systematic completeness in data collection.
- Return the results in a markdown fenced code block CSV format without any inline citations generated by the AI system.

This research requires meticulous attention to detail and an exhaustive approach. Ensure full epistemological rigor in every step.

async_task_status_messages.initial: Comprehensive Research on Spatial Analyst Tool

parts:
```csv
"Tool","Year","Source","URL","AI Notes"
"Spatial Analyst","1999","Applying GIS to Archaeological Site Prediction on Camp Pendleton, Southern California","https://pcas.org/Vol35N1/351Reddy.pdf","Used ArcView Spatial Analyst extension to derive slope and create predictive site probability maps."
"Spatial Analyst","1999","Digital Cartographical Databases and Their Application to Archaeology (CAA 1998 Proceedings)","https://bibliographie.uni-tuebingen.de/xmlui/bitstream/handle/10900/60763/22_Baena_et_al_CAA_1998.pdf","Published 1999; mentions ArcView Spatial Analyst extension as one of the GIS tools for integrating raster data in archaeology."
"Spatial Analyst","2001","Estimating the Minimum Number of Skeletal Elements (MNE) in Zooarchaeology: A Review and a New Image-Analysis GIS Approach","https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/american-antiquity/article/estimating-the-minimum-number-of-skeletal-elements-mne-in-zooarchaeology-a-review-and-a-new-imageanalysis-gis-approach/04B1C77BA13C5D3CB7C189B9FF45F5B4","American Antiquity 66(2) 2001; used ArcView GIS 3.1 with the Spatial Analyst extension v3.0 on Windows 95/98 for zooarchaeological analysis."
"Spatial Analyst","2002","Mn/Model Final Report Phases 1–3 (Chapter 11: Mn/Model Implementation)","https://www.dot.state.mn.us/mnmodel/P3FinalReport/chapter11.html","Published 2002; notes that ArcView's Spatial Analyst extension is required to use Mn/Model’s archaeological predictive models."
"Spatial Analyst","2003","Spatial Analysis and Archaeological Resources in the Finger Lakes National Forest","https://orb.binghamton.edu/neha/vol32/iss1/8/","Northeast Historical Archaeology Vol. 32 (2003); demonstrates use of ArcView’s Spatial Analyst extension to model spatial characteristics of site data."
"Spatial Analyst","2003","Cultural Landscapes of Coastal Foragers: An Example of GIS and Drainage Catchment Analysis from Southern California","https://www.esri.com/content/dam/esrisites/sitecore-archive/Files/Pdfs/library/journals/archaeology/volume_1/drainage_catchment_analysis.pdf","Journal of GIS in Archaeology, Vol. I (April 2003); used ArcView GIS 3.2 with Spatial Analyst and 3D Analyst extensions to produce DEMs and watershed catchment analyses for archaeological sites."
"Spatial Analyst","2007","Archaeology and Geoinformatics, Issue 4 (CD-ROM publication, Inst. of Archaeology RAN)","https://archaeolog.ru/media/periodicals/agis/AGIS-4/Koshelenko/english.html","Published 2007; includes a study in the Kislovodsk region where ArcGIS Spatial Analyst (and 3D Analyst) were used for GIS data processing (English summary available)."
"Spatial Analyst","2009","GIS for Archaeology (Esri GIS Best Practices)","https://www.esri.com/content/dam/esrisites/sitecore-archive/Files/Pdfs/library/bestpractices/archaeology.pdf","Published July 2009; compendium of case studies (e.g., Aztec sites) where ArcGIS Spatial Analyst extension was employed for tasks like georeferencing historical maps and hydrological modeling."
"Spatial Analyst","2012","Reconstruction of the closest communications to the Old Rus’ sites in the microregion of Khotyn Elevation with the help of Spatial Analyst: Methodical aspect","https://archaeolog.ru/media/periodicals/agis/AGIS-7/Manigda/english.html","Archaeology and Geoinformatics, Issue 7 (2012); methodological article showcasing use of ArcGIS Spatial Analyst for reconstructing ancient route networks (from English summary)."
"Spatial Analyst","2018","Digital Elevation Models Bring Mining History to Life","https://www.esri.com/about/newsroom/arcnews/digital-elevation-models-bring-mining-history-to-life/","ArcNews Summer 2018; describes how Alpine Archaeological Consultants used ArcGIS Spatial Analyst (hillshade and other tools) with lidar to document an abandoned Colorado mining town site."
"Spatial Analyst","2023","Unraveling the Mongolian Arc: a Field Survey and Spatial Analysis [in Mongolia]","https://doi.org/10.1080/00934690.2023.2295198","Journal of Field Archaeology (2023); reports conducting analyses using ArcGIS Pro Spatial Analyst toolbox (v3.1.3) on 90m DEM data as part of an archaeological field survey in Mongolia."
```

metadata.async_task_title: Comprehensive Research on Spatial Analyst Tool
